abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment of the
            Emergency Transport Rehabilitation Project identifies the
            potential negative environmental impacts of
            Kabul-Salang-Doshi and Pole-e Khomri-Kunduz Roads. The
            impacts on land resources and land use may result in
            unstable mountain slopes, avalanche, and falling rocks; as
            well as land degradation and erosion due to improper
            disposal of cut and borrow material. Roads built on mountain
            slopes accumulate rainwater runoffs, causing potential
            erosion problems. Irrigation channels within the road's
            right of way may damage the pavements. There may be
            groundwater and surface water pollution during construction
            and maintenance. Spillage and leakage from motor vehicles
            could have negative effects. Additional dust and noise
            levels are expected during construction. To mitigate these
            impacts, specific measures will be taken to reduce the
            potential impacts of physical works, including devising
            acceptable safety measures, designs to limit erosion
            problems in flat plain zones and mountain roads, and
            incorporating traffic safety designs and improved access
            points for villagers living along the roads. In the civil
            aviation component, clearance of landmines is the most
            important safety issue facing the Kabul Airport.
